column1: '''Jemima Catlin''' (b. [[27 October]] [[1986]]) is a British artist who illustrated the [[2013]] edition of ''[[The Hobbit]]'' and the subsequent ''[[Tolkien Calendar 2014]]''.
Catlin first encountered ''[[The Hobbit]]'' when she was 12, as her grandfather was a Tolkien fan and collector. She studied a Diploma in Art and Design at [[wikipedia:Weymouth College
column2: Weymouth College]] and continued studying Visual Communication at the [[wikipedia:Arts University Bournemouth
column3: Arts University at Bournemouth]] before graduating with a degree in Illustration in June 2010.<ref name="Foes">{{webcite
column6: articlename=Interview: Jemima Catlin, Illustrator of “The Hobbit”
column8: accessed=24 October 2015}}</ref> She lives in Dorchester, England with her husband.<ref name="Library"/>

column1: As part of her final project in her degree, Catlin chose to illustrate ''[[Roverandom]]''. After sending the images to [[David Brawn]] at [[HarperCollins]], he invited her to their offices in London; although [[Christopher Tolkien]] did not feel that Catlin's style suited ''Roverandom'', Christopher and his wife [[Baillie Tolkien
column2: Baillie]] were sufficiently enamoured of her work to commission her to illustrate ''[[The Hobbit]]'' a year later.<ref name="Library">{{webcite
column5: articlename=Interview with Jemima Catlin about the new illustrated edition of The Hobbit

column4: Jemima Catlin's illustrated version of ''[[The Hobbit]]'']]

column2: This edition needed to appeal to children, but The Hobbit is loved by all ages so I tried to illustrate it in a way that both audiences would enjoy it. My main influence were Tolkien’s own drawings, I really loved his illustrations and wanted to stay true to how he wanted the characters/landscapes to look. I adore Alan Lee’s work, his style is so detailed and photo-realistic, but so different from my own that I didn’t find it influenced me. I love the films and have seen The Lord of The Rings trilogy numerous times. My depiction of The Hobbit was just how I saw it in my imagination and it happened to be quite different to Peter Jackson’s vision. Tolkien had done lots of illustrations for The Hobbit and these were my inspiration – I really wanted to bring The Hobbit back to its original roots.
column3: Jemima Catlin on comparison with [[Alan Lee]]<ref>{{webcite

column1: The completed version of ''[[The Hobbit]]'' took over two years to illustrate, included 150 illustrations and was released on [[12 September]] [[2013]] (the same day as ''[[Tolkien Calendar 2014]]'').<ref>{{webcite
column4: articlename=Bringing Us There and Back Again: An Interview with Jemima Catlin
column6: accessed=24 October 2015}}</ref> Two weeks later Catlin exhibited her artwork at [[The Tolkien Society]]'s [[Oxonmoot 2013]] event. She describes herself as "proud" of her achievement, whilst still expressing a desire to illustrate either ''Roverandom'' or ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]''.<ref name="Legendarium">{{webcite

column1: Catlin's artistic style has been compared to [[Tove Jansson]] (illustrator of ''[[wikipedia:Moomin
column2: The Moomins]]'' and a Swedish edition of ''The Hobbit''), [[wikipedia:E. H. Shepard
column4: Winnie-the-Pooh]]'') as well as the anime style of [[wikipedia:Studio Ghibli
column5: Studio Ghibli]].<ref name="Foes"/> Catlin herself states that she was only influenced by Tolkien's own drawings whilst deliberately avoiding the films.<ref name="Library"/>
